newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Herzog says Slovenia EU vote delay strange.
newsitem.headline: Herzog says Slovenia EU vote delay strange.

text.p: German President Roman Herzog expressed surprise on Saturday at a delay in Slovenia's ratification of an association agreement with the European Union signed a year ago.
"It is strange that the agreement has not been ratified yet," Herzog told a news conference at a two-day meeting of presidents of eight central European countries on Slovenia's Adriatic coast.
Parliament has dragged its feet in voting on the accord because changes are needed to Slovenia's constitution before the agreement can be deemed legal.

Herzog said he agreed with Slovenian President Milan Kucan that the former Yugoslav republic could still be included in the first round of the EU enlargement, provided it made the necessary constitutional changes soon.
The national charter has to be amended to allow foreigners to buy land, a requirement necessary for EU membership.
"Our problem is not ratification but rather the change to the Slovenian constitution. If we change the constitution, the question of ratification will no longer remain an issue," Kucan said.
The constitutional court on Thursday ruled that the constitution had to be changed before a vote could go ahead.

European Commission President Jacques Santer said in April that Slovenia's speedy ratification of the association accord was a precondition for it to be included in the first group of states that will start negotiations on EU membership, probably in 1998.
In May, Kucan urged parliament to ratify the EU agreement and to change the constitution as soon as possible, claiming it was in Slovenia's vital interest.
"The goal of our independence was to join international organisations, among them the EU," Kucan said.
